all_paragraphs: List is a built-in data structure in Python. It is represented as a collection of data points in square brackets. Lists can be used to store any data type or a mixture of different data types.
Lists are mutable which is one of the reasons why they are so commonly used. However, mutability needs extra caution in some cases.
In this post, we will cover 11 very important operations that cover almost all you need to know about Python lists.
The first way is the del function. We just past the index of the element to be removed.
We can use the remove function which looks for the value to be removed.

The third way is the pop function which removes the last element of a list by default. Unlike the other two functions, pop returns the value that is removed. Thus, we have the option to assign it to a different variable.

Edit: Pop is commonly used to pop out (or remove) the last element of a list. However, it can also be used to remove any element by providing the index. Thanks Keethesh for the heads up in the comments.

Append is used to add an item to a list.
Whatever you append to a list, it will become an item of the list.
List b became the third item of list a. If you wanted to create a list that is the combination of the items in a and b ([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]), you need to use the extend function or “+” operator.

The insert function is also used to add an element to a list. However, it allows specifying the index of the new element. For instance, we can add a new element at the beginning of the list (index=0).
The first parameter is the index and the second one is the value.
We can copy a list and create a new variable.
However, the new variable “b” is just a pointer to the values of “a”. Thus, any change in a also changes b. Let’s confirm by adding a value to a.
We can copy a list by selecting its all indices.
The new list b contains the same values as a but at a different memory location. If we make a change in a, b won’t be affected.
Copying a list by using the copy function works the same as copying with indices.

List comprehension is basically creating lists based on existing iterables. It achieves what can be done with for loops in a faster way. The syntax of a list comprehension is also simpler and more appealing than that of for loops.

Note: List comprehension loads the entire output list into memory which makes it faster than a for loop. It is desirable to use list comprehensions when working with small or medium-sized lists. However, when we are working with large lists (e.g. 1 billion elements), list comprehension should be avoided. It may cause your computer to crash due to the extreme amount of memory requirement.
